case_name: Dr. Akshaibar Lal & Ors. v. Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 480 to 487 of 1960 were filed in the Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 480 to 487 of 1960. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 15, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 1554, 1561, 1553, 1560, 1556, 1558, 1559 and 1557 of 1960.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court delivered judgment and order dated July 15, 1960, dismissing writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 15, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ Nos. 1554, 1561, 1553, 1560, 1556, 1558, 1559 and 1557 of 1960.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions Nos. 1554, 1561, 1553, 1560, 1556, 1558, 1559 and 1557 of 1960 in Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Nos. 1554, 1561, 1553, 1560, 1556, 1558, 1559 and 1557 of 1960. NC. Chatterjee, R. K. Garg, S. C. Agarwal, D. P. Singh, K. Sinha, V. A. Seyid Muhamad and M. K. Ramamurthi, for the appellants  in C. As. Nos. 480 and 481 of 60 . RK. Garg, M. K. Ramamurthi, S. C. Agarwal, D. P. Singh, A. Seyid Muhamad and K. K. Sinha, for the appellants  in As. Nos. 482 to 487 of 60 . N. Kunzru and I. N. Shroff, for the respondents. 1961. January 10.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 10, 1961 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-These are eight appeals against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Allahabad dated July 15, 1960, with special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Executive Council of Banaras Hindu University passed Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 on May 15, 1960, terminating appellants' services from June 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: By the writ petitions, which failed before the High Court, the appellants had asked that Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 passed by the Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University on May 15, 1960, terminating their services from June 1, 1960, be quashed.

facts.text: Dr. Akshaibar Lal was Reader in College of Agriculture.

anchor.surface_text: Group I Dr. Akshaibar Lal Reader in College of A. No. 480 of 1960  Agriculture.  Resolution No. 100-4months pay in lieu of numberice

facts.text: Dr. Gopal Tripathi was Professor of Chemical Engineering and Principal, College of Technology.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Gopal Tripathi Professor of Chemi- A. No. 482 of 1960  cal Engineering and Principal, College of Technology.  Resolution No. 101-4months pay in lieu of numberice

facts.text: Pandit Ram Vyas Pandey was Reader and Head of Department of Jyotish-Sanskrit Mahavidyalaya.

anchor.surface_text: Pandit Ram Vyas Pandey Reader and Head of A. No. 486 of 1960  Department of Jyotish- Sanskrit Maha- vidyalaya.  Resolution No. 99---under cls. 4 and 7 of the agreement dated March 26, 1931

facts.text: President of India appointed Mudaliar Committee to enquire into University affairs.

anchor.surface_text: The President of India, in his capacity as Visitor and in exercise of the powers conferred by s. 5 2  of the Banaras Hindu University Act, 1915, appointed a Committee of Enquiry  known as the Mudaliar Committee  consisting of Dr. A. L. Mudaliar  President  Mr. M. C. Mahajan Dr. P. Subbarayan Smt. Sucheta Kripalani Dr. Nairoji Wadia  Members

facts.text: President promulgated Ordinance IV of 1958 on June 14, 1958, amending Banaras Hindu University Act.

anchor.surface_text: On June 14, 1958, the President of India promulgated an Ordinance  IV of 1958  to amend the Banaras Hindu University Act, 1915. By s. 8 of the Ordinance, the Statutes of the University were amended

facts.text: Ordinance IV of 1958 repealed by Banaras Hindu University Amendment Act, 1958 (XXXIV of 1958).

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance of the President was repealed by the Banaras Hindu University  Amendment  Act, 1958  XXXIV of 1958 , which re-enacted Statute No. 30 as follows 30.  1  If the Executive Council has reason to believe

facts.text: Solicitor-General referred appellants' cases to Reviewing Committee.

anchor.surface_text: Under the powers granted by this Statute and after sundry procedure, the Solicitor-General sent up the cases of the appellants  and some others, who are not before us  to the Reviewing Committee.

facts.text: Appellants appeared before the Reviewing Committee.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants appeared before the Reviewing Committee and represented their cases. Except in the case of Mr. Radhey Shyam Sharma  Civil Appeal No. 484 of 1960 , whose case was kept pending

facts.text: Executive Council passed Resolutions Nos. 436 to 439 on February 13, 1960, calling Group I appellants to show cause.

anchor.surface_text: These findings were considered in respect of the four appellants in Group I  above , and on February 13, 1960, the Executive Council passed Resolutions Nos. 436 to 439 calling upon them to show cause why their services be not terminated

facts.text: Group I appellants showed cause on March 5, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: These four appellants showed cause on March 5, 1960, No notices were, however, sent to the four appellants in Group II above, and this is one distinguishing feature in the cases.

facts.text: Group I appellants filed writ petitions W. Ps. Nos. 712 to 715 of 1960 on March 9, 1960, in Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The four appellants  Group I  filed petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution  W. Ps. Nos. 712 to 715 of 1960  on March 9,1960, in the High Court of Allahabad for relief against the proposed action.

facts.text: D. S. Mathur, J. passed ad interim order on March 9, 1960, directing no further proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day D. S. Mathur, J. passed an ad interim order as follows The respondents Nos. 1 to 3 are directed until further orders, not to take any further proceedings against the petitioners.

facts.text: Jagdish Sahai, J. modified stay order on April 25, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar of the University then applied to the High Court, and on April 25, 1960, Jagdish Sahai, J., made the following order In supersession of the interim order dated 9-3-1960

facts.text: Executive Council passed Resolution No. 89 on May 15, 1960, postponing consideration of Group I cases.

anchor.surface_text: On May 15, 1960, the Executive Council of the University passed a number of Resolutions. Resolution No. 89 took into consideration the explanations sent by the four appellants  Group 1  on March 5, 1960

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed all eight writ petitions by common judgment.

anchor.surface_text: It was after these Resolutions were communicated that the eight petitions were filed by the appellants in the High Court of Allahabad. The High Court by a common judgment, which is under appeal, dismissed all the petitions with costs.

facts.text: Supreme Court quashed Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals are allowed. Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960, of the Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University are quashed

facts.text: Affairs of Banaras Hindu University were deteriorating requiring immediate intervention.

anchor.surface_text: The affairs of the Banaras Hindu University, for reasons with which we are not concerned, had been deteriorating, and a situation had arisen which required intervention immediately.

facts.text: No notices sent to Group II appellants under Statute 30.

anchor.surface_text: No notices were, however, sent to the four appellants in Group II above, and this is one distinguishing feature in the cases.

facts.text: Reviewing Committee kept Mr. Radhey Shyam Sharma's case pending as sub judice.

anchor.surface_text: Except in the case of Mr. Radhey Shyam Sharma  Civil Appeal No. 484 of 1960 , whose case was kept pending because certain matters were sub judice, the Reviewing Committee sent its findings to the University.

issues.text: whether after the special procedure under Statute No. 30 was once invoked, it could be dropped in the middle and other powers exercised

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether after the special procedure was once invoked, it could be dropped in the middle and other powers exercised. The University relies on three arguments in this connection.

issues.text: whether the powers under agreements, Ordinance No. 6 and Statute No. 30 are cumulative or alternative such that the Executive Council could resort to any after invoking Statute No. 30

anchor.surface_text: where the law allows alternative remedies, one or the other or both can be invoked unless one remedy is expressly or by necessary implication excluded by the other

issues.text: what is the correct interpretation of Ordinance No. 6 regarding the power to terminate services without cause on notice

anchor.surface_text: Ordinance No. 6, before its amendment, read The Executive Council shall be entitled to terminate the engagement of an employee

issues.text: whether clause 5 of Statute No. 30 conferred discretion on the Executive Council to abandon the procedure and take no action on the Reviewing Committee's recommendations

anchor.surface_text: The next argument is that Statute No. 30 itself left liberty of action, inasmuch as cl. 5 gave power to the Executive Council to act as it thought fit.

issues.text: whether the Executive Council as appointing authority had inherent power to terminate services under sections 4(7), 4(13) of the Act and s.16 General Clauses Act independently

anchor.surface_text: reference is made to ss. 4 7  and 4 13  of the Act and s. 16 of the General Clauses Act.

issues.text: whether the Executive Council could not take recourse to Ordinance No. 6 having started action under Statute No. 30 as Ordinance is subordinate

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellants, broadly stated, is that the Executive Council could not take recourse to the provisions of Ordinance No. 6 of the Ordinances of the University, having started action under Statute No. 30,

arguments.claim: Executive Council could not take recourse to Ordinance No. 6 after starting action under Statute No. 30 as Ordinance is subordinate to Statute

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellants, broadly stated, is that the Executive Council could not take recourse to the provisions of Ordinance No. 6 of the Ordinances of the University, having started action under Statute No. 30, that Ordinance No. 6 was subordinate to, Statute No. 30

arguments.court_reasoning: Ordinances subordinate to Statutes; special procedure under Statute 30 excludes general powers once invoked

anchor.surface_text: Ordinance No. 6, before its amendment, read The Executive Council shall be entitled to terminate the engagement of an employee ... The High Court was persuaded to read the clause as interpreted by the University and, in our opinion, rightly.

arguments.claim: Powers under Ordinance 6 subject to Statutes; cannot prevail over Statute 30

arguments.claim: Once special procedure under Statute 30 invoked for cases where continuance detrimental, cannot abandon mid-way and use general powers

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether after the special procedure was once invoked, it could be dropped in the middle and other powers exercised.

arguments.claim: Alternative remedies excluded by necessary implication under Statute 30 as special procedure for special circumstances

anchor.surface_text: where the law allows alternative remedies, one or the other or both can be invoked unless one remedy is expressly or by necessary implication excluded by the other  See State

arguments.claim: Dropping Statute 30 procedure deprives right to show cause against Reviewing Committee findings

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out here that dropping of action under Statute No. 30 deprived the appellants of the right to show cause against what had been alleged against them or found by the Reviewing Committee.

arguments.claim: Impugned resolutions ultra vires as abandoned special procedure under Statute 30

anchor.surface_text: the impugned Resolutions were ultra vires and should be quashed.

holdings.text: The impugned Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960, were ultra vires and should be quashed.

anchor.surface_text: the impugned Resolutions were ultra vires and should be quashed. In the result, the appeals are allowed. Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960, of the Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University are quashed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Once special procedure under Statute 30 invoked for cases detrimental to university interests, cannot abandon midway and resort to general powers under Ordinances or agreements as Ordinances subordinate to Statutes and special procedure excludes general by implication.

holdings.text: Powers under agreements, Ordinance No. 6, and Statute No. 30 are not cumulative or alternative such that Executive Council can resort to general powers after invoking Statute 30.

anchor.surface_text: where the law allows alternative remedies, one or the other or both can be invoked unless one remedy is expressly or by necessary implication excluded by the other. The question thus is whether there is anything expressly stated by law or clearly implied which would exclude powers under the agreements and the Ordinances, when action has been taken under the Statutes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute 30 enacted for special situation excludes general powers by necessary implication once commenced; Ordinances expressly subject to Statutes per s.18; dropping deprives hearing rights.

holdings.text: Ordinance No. 6 permits termination without cause on four months' notice or salary in lieu, separate from termination for misconduct, unfitness, inefficiency requiring explanation.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinance No. 6, before its amendment, read The Executive Council shall be entitled to terminate the engagement of an employee ... The High Court was persuaded to read the clause as interpreted by the University and, in our opinion, rightly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation by rearranging poorly drafted clause; agrees with High Court; distinguishes cause-based termination requiring hearing from simple notice termination.

holdings.text: Clause 5 of Statute 30 does not confer discretion to abandon procedure but requires completing enquiry by taking action on Reviewing Committee recommendations within Statute.

anchor.surface_text: The next argument is that Statute No. 30 itself left liberty of action, inasmuch as cl. 5 gave power to the Executive Council to act as it thought fit. ... The words are permissive, no doubt, as to the choice of action, but are imperative in so far as they require some act completing the intent and purpose of the enquiry itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'shall take such action thereon as it may think fit' permissive on choice but imperative to complete purpose; no discretion outside Statute.

holdings.text: Executive Council did not correctly exercise inherent termination power under ss. 4(7), 4(13) of Act and s.16 General Clauses Act as must follow Statutes and Ordinances.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it is argued that the Executive Council as the appointing authority had the power also to dismiss, and reference is made to ss. 4 7  and 4 13  of the Act and s. 16 of the General Clauses Act. None can deny that the University did possess such a power. The question is whether it exercised it correctly under the Statutes and Ordinances. We are quite clear that the Executive Council did not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power exists but must be exercised per Statutes/Ordinances; here violated by abandoning Statute 30.

holdings.text: Action of Executive Council not based on malice, indirect or oblique motive.

anchor.surface_text: We may say here that we have not accepted the contention that the action of the Executive Council was based upon malice or any indirect or oblique motive. The error was in thinking that there were cumulative or alternative powers, even after the adoption of the special procedure under Statute No. 30.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court not concerned with motives but legality; no proof, focus on ultra vires.

holdings.text: Executive Council could not take recourse to Ordinance No. 6 having started action under Statute No. 30 as Ordinance subordinate to Statute.

anchor.surface_text: The powers granted by the Ordinances are expressly subject to the Statutes, and the Ordinances cannot prevail over the Statutes. Statute No. 30 provided for special action in special circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18 Act subordinates Ordinances to Statutes; special excludes general once invoked.

precedents.cited_proposition: the Court can interfere with an act of a public body which is on the face of it regular and within its powers only if ultra vires; bad faith etc. are examples of ultra vires
precedents.cited_holding: My view then is that only case in which the Court can interfere with an act of a public body which is, on the face of it, regular and within its powers, is when it is proved to be in fact ultra vires, and that the references... are merely intended... as examples of matters which if proved to exist might establish the ultra vires character of the action in question

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals are allowed. Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960, of the Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University are quashed, and an appropriate writ or writs shall issue to the respondents to that effect.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals allowed; Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960 quashed; writs to issue quashing the resolutions terminating services
directions: Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960, of the Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University are quashed
an appropriate writ or writs shall issue to the respondents to that effect
The respondents shall pay the costs of these appeals, as also of the High Court

anchor.surface_text: where the law allows alternative remedies, one or the other or both can be invoked unless one remedy is expressly or by necessary implication excluded by the other. The question thus is whether there is anything expressly stated by law or clearly implied which would exclude powers under the agreements and the Ordinances, when action has been taken under the Statutes.

In the result, the appeals are allowed. Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960, of the Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University are quashed, and an appropriate writ or writs shall issue to the respondents to that effect.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinance No. 6, before its amendment, read The Executive Council shall be entitled to terminate the engagement of an employee ... The High Court was persuaded to read the clause as interpreted by the University and, in our opinion, rightly.

In the result, the appeals are allowed. Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960, of the Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University are quashed, and an appropriate writ or writs shall issue to the respondents to that effect.

edges.explanation: h4 directly addresses whether clause 5 confers discretion to abandon Statute 30 procedure

anchor.surface_text: The next argument is that Statute No. 30 itself left liberty of action, inasmuch as cl. 5 gave power to the Executive Council to act as it thought fit. ... The words are permissive, no doubt, as to the choice of action, but are imperative in so far as they require some act completing the intent and purpose of the enquiry itself.

In the result, the appeals are allowed. Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960, of the Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University are quashed, and an appropriate writ or writs shall issue to the respondents to that effect.
The next argument is that Statute No. 30 itself left liberty of action, inasmuch as el. 5 gave power to the Executive Council to act as it thought fit

edges.explanation: Holding addresses the issue by determining that termination power under ss. 4(7), 4(13) and s.16 was not correctly exercised

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it is argued that the Executive Council as the appointing authority had the power also to dismiss, and reference is made to ss. 4 7  and 4 13  of the Act and s. 16 of the General Clauses Act. None can deny that the University did possess such a power. The question is whether it exercised it correctly under the Statutes and Ordinances. We are quite clear that the Executive Council did not.

In the result, the appeals are allowed. Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960, of the Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University are quashed, and an appropriate writ or writs shall issue to the respondents to that effect.

anchor.surface_text: We may say here that we have not accepted the contention that the action of the Executive Council was based upon malice or any indirect or oblique motive. The error was in thinking that there were cumulative or alternative powers, even after the adoption of the special procedure under Statute No. 30.
on to all other powers vested in it, have the following powers, namely To appoint, from time to time, Principals of Colleges and institutions establis

edges.explanation: h7 directly addresses whether Executive Council could take recourse to Ordinance No. 6 after starting Statute No. 30

anchor.surface_text: The powers granted by the Ordinances are expressly subject to the Statutes, and the Ordinances cannot prevail over the Statutes. Statute No. 30 provided for special action in special circumstances.

In the result, the appeals are allowed. Resolutions Nos. 90, 94 to 96 and 99 to 102 dated May 15, 1960, of the Executive Council of the Banaras Hindu University are quashed, and an appropriate writ or writs shall issue to the respondents to that effect.
